choices.text: Regular uterine contractions without cervical change
Cervical length < 2.5 cm on transvaginal sonography

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a diagnostic criterion for preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Preterm labour diagnosis requires both regular uterine contractions and objective evidence of cervical change. The absence of cervical change despite contractions does not fulfil the diagnostic criteria.

Explanation of Other Options:

Regular uterine contractions without pain (Option A): Contractions can be painless initially; the presence of pain is not essential for diagnosis if cervical change is observed.

Cervical dilation > 2 cm (Option B): Objective cervical change supports the diagnosis.

Cervical length < 2.5 cm on TVS (Option D): A cervical length < 2.5 cm is a validated predictor of preterm birth, especially when combined with uterine contractions.

questions.text: Which of the following maternal conditions is not associated with preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple maternal conditions are associated with an increased risk of preterm labour. Multiparity alone, in the absence of other risk factors, is not a recognised independent risk factor.

  • Recognised maternal risk factors include:

questions.text: All the following are known causes of preterm labour except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Placenta accreta is not an established risk factor for preterm labour.

Known causes and risk factors for preterm labour include:

  • History-related factors:
    • Previous preterm birth (most important risk factor)
    • Induced or spontaneous abortion
    • Pregnancy following ART
  • Maternal factors:
    • Smoking
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Poor nutritional status
    • Maternal stress
    • Asymptomatic bacteriuria or recurrent UTI
  • Fetal and placental factors:
    • Multiple pregnancies
    • Congenital malformations
    • Intrauterine fetal death (IUFD)
    • Placental infarction, thrombosis
    • Placenta previa, placental abruption

Placenta accreta, while a serious obstetric condition, is typically associated with abnormal placental adherence and postpartum haemorrhage, not preterm labour initiation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a predictor of preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history of preterm birth, multiple gestation, and genital tract infections are all validated clinical predictors of spontaneous preterm birth.

  • Clinical Predictors:
    • History of prior preterm birth (Option A)
    • Multiple pregnancy (Option B)
    • Genital tract infection (Option C)
  • Biophysical Predictors:
    • Uterine contractions > 4/hour
    • Bishop score > 4
    • Cervical length < 25 mm on TVS
  • Biochemical Predictors:
    • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervicovaginal discharge
    • Inflammatory markers (e.g., IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α)

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida patient came to the hospital at 35 weeks of gestation complaining of abdominal pain. She denied having any vaginal discharge. She had regular uterine contractions, and her cervical length was 2 cm on transvaginal sonography (TVS). The obstetrician performed a fetal fibronectin (fFN) test, which was positive. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A diagnosis of preterm labour is based on clinical findings of:

  • Regular uterine contractions accompanied by cervical dilation ≥ 2 cm, effacement, or both.
  • Positive fFN test, which indicates extracellular matrix remodelling and is associated with impending preterm birth.
  • The absence of vaginal discharge helps rule out PROM.

Explanation of Other Options:

IUGR (Option A): Refers to impaired fetal growth, not primarily diagnosed via contractions or cervical changes.

IUD (Option B): Intrauterine death would require absent fetal heart activity, not contraction-based findings.

PROM (Option D): Characterised by rupture of membranes, typically presenting with vaginal fluid leakage.

choices.text: In this test, fFN is measured from the maternal serum
A Positive test in the first trimester increases the risk of abortion
A negative test means delivery will not occur in the next 7 days

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the fetal fibronectin (fFN) test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fetal fibronectin (fFN) is a glycoprotein produced at the maternal-fetal interface and functions in implantation and placental adhesion. It is found in cervicovaginal secretions normally before 22 weeks and after 37 weeks of gestation.

However, its presence between 24 and 34 weeks indicates disruption at the chorion-decidua interface and is associated with an increased risk of preterm labour.

  • A negative fFN test has a high negative predictive value, meaning delivery is highly unlikely within the next 7 days.
  • This test is done using a vaginal swab, not maternal serum.
  • fFN is not predictive in the first trimester and is not used to assess abortion risk.

Explanation of Other Options:

In this test, fFN is measured from maternal serum (Option A): fFN is detected from vaginal secretions, not maternal serum.

A positive test in the first trimester increases the risk of abortion (Option B): fFN is not clinically useful or interpreted in the first trimester.

questions.text: All of the following are routinely used in the management of preterm labour with intact membranes except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In women with preterm labour and intact membranes, routine use of prophylactic antibiotics is not recommended.

  • Antibiotics are reserved for preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) to prolong latency and reduce neonatal morbidity.
  • The other interventions are standard in managing preterm labour to improve neonatal outcomes.

choices.text: Cervical incompetency with threatened preterm labor

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is cervical cerclage not performed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cerclage is not performed in women with PPROM due to the increased risk of infection. It is contraindicated once the membranes have ruptured, regardless of cervical length.

  • Cervical insufficiency (Option A) → Classic indication for cerclage.
  • Short cervix on TVS (Option B) → Sonographic cerclage may be offered in selected high-risk women.
  • Threatened preterm labour with cervical incompetency (Option C) → Emergency or rescue cerclage may be considered.
  • PPROM (Option D) → Contraindicated due to risk of ascending infection.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts the McDonald cerclage, a commonly performed cervical stitch procedure. It is a simple purse-string suture placed at the cervicovaginal junction without bladder dissection or removal of the vaginal mucosa.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1 woman with a history of previous preterm delivery presents for an antenatal visit at 20 weeks of gestation. She has no abdominal pain or vaginal discharge. A transvaginal ultrasound at 19 weeks reveals a cervical length of 2 cm with funnelling of the internal os. On per speculum examination, herniation of fetal membranes is noted through the cervical os. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This case is diagnostic of cervical insufficiency, evidenced by painless cervical shortening with funnelling and herniation of membranes in the second trimester. Cerclage is the recommended intervention to reduce the risk of further cervical dilation and preterm birth.

Key Diagnostic Features:

  • History of prior preterm birth
  • Cervical length < 25 mm on transvaginal ultrasound
  • Funnelling of internal os > 1 cm
  • Herniation of membranes on speculum exam

Management:

  • Emergency/rescue cerclage is indicated if cervical dilatation and herniation are present with no signs of labour or infection.
  • Tocolytics and steroids are not first-line in the absence of uterine contractions or viability concerns.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tocolytic drugs only (Option A): Tocolytics are used to suppress active uterine contractions, which are absent in this patient. Without signs of preterm labour, they are not indicated.

Tocolytic drugs and steroids (Option B): Steroids are typically given after 24 weeks to enhance fetal lung maturity; the patient is only at 20 weeks. Moreover, there are no contractions warranting tocolytics.

Steroids only (Option C): Steroids alone are inappropriate here. There's no imminent preterm labour, and gestational age is before fetal viability. Cerclage addresses the actual pathology.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most serious complication of PROM?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chorioamnionitis is the most serious and common complication of premature rupture of membranes (PROM), especially when delivery is delayed. The risk of ascending infection increases significantly if labour fails to start within 24 hours, leading to maternal and fetal sepsis.

Key Dangers of PROM:

Explanation of Other Options:

Placental abruption (Option A): Can occur in PROM but is less common and usually not the most immediate or life-threatening complication.

Retained placenta (Option C): A known complication post-delivery, but not the most serious during PROM.

IUGR (Option D): Generally associated with chronic placental insufficiency, not directly with PROM unless prolonged oligohydramnios develops early.

choices.text: Rupture of membranes 24 hr before delivery
Rupture of membranes before 37 completed weeks
Rupture of membranes before the active stage of labour

questions.text: Prolonged rupture of membranes is defined as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rupture of membranes persisting for more than 24 hours before delivery is termed prolonged rupture of membranes and is associated with an increased risk of maternal and fetal infection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rupture of membranes before labour (Option B): Describes PROM, not prolonged ROM.

Rupture of membranes before 37 completed weeks (Option C): Describes PPROM.

Rupture of membranes before the active stage of labour (Option D): Not a standard classification term.

choices.text: It reduces the incidence of IVH in preterm babies
Injection betamethasone is given as 6 mg IM, 4 doses
Injection dexamethasone is given as 12 mg IM, 2 doses

questions.text: Regarding the use of glucocorticoids in preterm labour, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A single course of antenatal corticosteroids is recommended for women with preterm labour or PROM between 24 and 34 weeks of gestation to reduce the risk of neonatal complications.

  • This therapy has been shown to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular haemorrhage (IVH), and necrotising enterocolitis (NEC).
  • Betamethasone is administered as 12 mg IM every 24 hours × 2 doses.
  • Dexamethasone is given as 6 mg IM every 12 hours × 4 doses.
  • These dosing regimens are not interchangeable.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents at 30 weeks of gestation with labour pain. On per speculum examination, the cervical os is found to be dilated with bulging membranes. Which of the following interventions is not appropriate in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rescue cerclage is not advised once cervical dilation has progressed significantly, especially after viability (~24 weeks), and particularly when the membranes are bulging. At 30 weeks, the focus should be on prolonging latency for steroid benefit and neonatal transport, not surgical intervention.

  • Tocolysis is administered to delay delivery up to 48 hours to allow corticosteroids to act. (Option B ruled out)
  • Steroids (e.g. betamethasone) are given to enhance fetal lung maturity. (Option D ruled out)
  • Bed rest may be considered, though not strongly evidence-based. (Option A ruled out)
  • Rescue cerclage, however, is generally not indicated after 24 weeks or once cervical dilation with bulging membranes has occurred.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of PROM except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oligohydramnios is not a cause but rather a complication or sequela of PROM, particularly in early gestation.

  • PROM is defined as rupture of membranes before the onset of labor. Most cases are idiopathic, but several contributing factors are well recognised.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for the diagnosis of rupture of membranes (PROM)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Kleihauer-Betke test is not used to diagnose PROM. It is used for the quantitative evaluation of fetomaternal haemorrhage by identifying fetal red cells in maternal blood using the acid elution technique.

PROM is confirmed using clinical and laboratory findings to detect leakage of amniotic fluid.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida patient came to the labour room with per vaginal leaking for 22 hr and fever upon examination; her temp is 100.4Â°F, her pulse is 100 bpm, and her BP is 110/70 mmHg. PROM is confirmed through per speculum examination. What is the most probable diagnosis for her?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fever accompanying ruptured membranes is a key diagnostic indicator of chorioamnionitis, especially when the temperature is ≥38°C (100.4°F).

Explanation of Other Options:

Intrauterine fetal death (Option A): Presents with absent fetal movements and no FHR on Doppler or NST; not the most probable diagnosis in this febrile patient with PROM.

Prolonged PROM (Option C): Defined as rupture of membranes >18 hours without labour. This patient has PROM, but fever points toward infection (chorioamnionitis), making this less likely.

Meconium-stained liquor (Option D): Diagnosed on visual inspection of amniotic fluid; not a diagnosis itself but a finding that may occur with fetal distress or post-term pregnancy.

questions.text: PROM at 32-week gestation management includes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tocolytics, progesterone therapy, and cervical cerclage are not recommended in the management of PROM. The correct and evidence-based approach in a patient with preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM) at 32 weeks is the administration of corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturity.

questions.text: MgSo4 in preterm labour is given for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is administered in preterm labour primarily for fetal neuroprotection. Studies have shown it significantly reduces the risk of cerebral palsy in very low-birthweight neonates when administered before anticipated preterm delivery.

  • MgSO4 is recommended between 24 to 32 weeks of gestation for neuroprotection when early delivery is anticipated.
  • Although MgSO4 has tocolytic and antihypertensive effects, these are not the primary indications in the context of preterm labour.
  • It is not a preferred tocolytic agent due to limited efficacy and maternal side effects.

Explanation of Other Options:

Control blood pressure (Option B): MgSO4 is used to prevent eclampsia in women with preeclampsia, not in isolated preterm labour.

Tocolysis (Option C): Although MgSO4 was previously used for this, current guidelines no longer recommend it as a first-line tocolytic.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of preterm delivery comes now with 32 weeks of pregnancy and labour pains with OS dilated 2 cm. What would be the ideal management for such a patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard management of preterm labour at 32 weeks includes antenatal corticosteroids to enhance fetal lung maturity and tocolysis for short-term pregnancy prolongation (up to 48 hours), mainly to complete steroid therapy and facilitate in utero transfer if needed.

  • Antenatal corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone or dexamethasone) reduce the risks of:
    • Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)
    • Intraventricular haemorrhage (IVH)
    • Necrotising enterocolitis (NEC)
    • Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD)
    • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  • Tocolytics may be used (unless contraindicated) to delay delivery for:
    • Completion of the corticosteroid course
    • Maternal transfer to a tertiary NICU-equipped centre

Explanation of Other Options:

Antibiotic and cerclage (Option B): Antibiotics are only given for Group B Streptococcus (GBS) prophylaxis if indicated, not routinely in all preterm labour cases. Cerclage is contraindicated once labour has started or the cervix is ≥2 cm dilated, as in this case. Cerclage is a preventive measure, not a treatment once labour is established.

Expectant management (Option C): Not advised in the setting of active labour at 32 weeks. Delay without intervention can increase the risks of neonatal morbidity. The goal is to prolong pregnancy briefly (using tocolytics) to complete antenatal corticosteroids, not passive observation.

Induction of labour (Option D): Induction is not appropriate unless there are maternal or fetal indications (e.g., chorioamnionitis, fetal distress). At 32 weeks, the preferred approach is to delay labour with tocolysis for steroid completion and arrange NICU delivery.

choices.text: Allow to go into spontaneous labour

questions.text: Management of PROM at 35 weeks of gestation:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For PROM between 34 - <37 weeks, the recommended management includes expectant monitoring for spontaneous labour.

  • Most patients deliver spontaneously within 24-48 hours.
  • If labour does not begin within this period, induction of labour may be initiated.
  • Routine tocolysis and steroids are not recommended beyond 34 weeks unless there are special indications.

Explanation of Other Options:

Steroid and tocolysis (Option B): Not routinely recommended after 34 weeks of gestation. Steroids are useful before 34 weeks to reduce neonatal RDS, and tocolysis is used to delay labour in earlier gestation to allow steroid administration.

Antibiotic and cerclage (Option C): Antibiotics are used if infection (e.g., GBS) is suspected or confirmed. Cerclage is contraindicated once PROM or labour has begun and is not appropriate at 35 weeks.

Immediate caesarean section (Option D): Not indicated solely for PROM at 35 weeks. Vaginal delivery is preferred unless obstetric indications (e.g., fetal distress, malpresentation) necessitate a cesarean.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1L1 presents to OPD at 35 weeks of pregnancy with C/O leaking per vaginum for two days. PROM is confirmed through per speculum examination. The temperature of the patient is 102° F, pulse is 102. The management is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with prolonged PROM (>24 hours) at 35 weeks, accompanied by fever and tachycardia, suggesting clinical chorioamnionitis. The standard management in this scenario includes:

  • Prompt induction of labour using oxytocin to minimise maternal and fetal risks.
  • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics should be started to manage intrauterine infection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Steroid and tocolysis (Option A): Both are contraindicated in the setting of infection. Steroids are avoided once chorioamnionitis is diagnosed, and tocolysis is never advised in PROM or active infection.

Antibiotics and tocolysis (Option B): Tocolytics are inappropriate and potentially harmful when infection is present.

Steroid and cerclage (Option C): Cerclage is contraindicated in PROM and infection; steroids are also avoided in chorioamnionitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to tocolysis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Preterm labour with bulging membranes is not an absolute contraindication to tocolysis. Though it may suggest advanced labour, tocolysis may still be cautiously attempted depending on the individual case, especially if the cervix is not fully dilated and membranes are still intact.

Absolute contraindications to tocolysis include:

(Other options are ruled out)

  • While bulging membranes indicate imminent rupture and advanced labour, tocolysis is not always contraindicated unless labour is well established or other contraindications are present.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a tocolytic drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nifedipine, a calcium-channel blocker, is an established and commonly used tocolytic agent. It reduces intracellular calcium levels, thereby inhibiting uterine contractions and delaying preterm labour.

Recommended tocolytic drug classes:

Explanation of Other Options:

Misoprostol (Option A): Prostaglandin E1 analogue; used for induction and cervical ripening, not for tocolysis.

Mifepristone (Option C): Antiprogestin; used for medical abortion, not as a tocolytic.

Drotaverine (Option D): Antispasmodic; not recommended or approved as a tocolytic agent.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant lady comes to visit an antenatal clinic with complaints of vaginal leaking. Which of the following is the next best step to check for PROM?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Per speculum examination is the best initial step in suspected PROM cases to directly visualise amniotic fluid leaking from the cervical os.

  • Digital vaginal examination is avoided due to the risk of introducing infection or precipitating labour.

choices.text: Serial CBC to check the total count
Serial vaginal examination to check dilatation of the cervix

questions.text: In cases of premature rupture of the membrane, all the following are acceptable in conservative management except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serial digital vaginal examination is avoided in the conservative management of PROM due to the increased risk of ascending infection. Repeated digital examinations are a recognised risk factor for chorioamnionitis, a serious intra-amniotic infection that can endanger both mother and fetus.

Additional risk factors for chorioamnionitis include:

  • Low parity
  • Use of internal uterine and fetal monitors
  • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
  • Colonisation or infection with Group B Streptococcus (GBS)
  • Presence of sexually transmitted infections (e.g., chlamydia, gonorrhoea)

choices.text: Steroid and allow to go into spontaneous labour

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 woman presents to the labour room at 38 weeks of gestation with a rupture of membranes. She currently denies having uterine contractions. What is the ideal next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In term pregnancies with PROM (≥37 weeks), induction of labour is recommended if spontaneous labour does not begin within 24 hours to reduce the risk of infection.

Management of PROM at Term (≥37 weeks):

  • PROM at term is associated with an increased risk of ascending infection, especially chorioamnionitis, if delivery is delayed.
  • Management involves:
    • Initial observation: Wait for the spontaneous onset of labour for 24 hours.
    • If labour doesn't begin, induction of labour with oxytocin is recommended.
    • Steroids are not indicated beyond 34 weeks of gestation.
    • Tocolytics are contraindicated in PROM due to the risk of infection.
    • Antibiotics are given only if there is GBS colonisation, prolonged PROM (>18-24 hr), or signs of infection.

PROM Management Based on Gestational Age:

Explanation of Other Options:

Antibiotics and tocolysis (Option B): Tocolysis is contraindicated at term PROM. Antibiotics are not routinely indicated unless GBS is positive or signs of infection are present.

Steroid and tocolysis (Option C): Steroids are only indicated <34 weeks. Tocolysis is contraindicated in PROM.

Steroid and allow to go in spontaneous labour (Option D): Allowing spontaneous labour up to 24 hr is acceptable, but steroids have no role at 38 weeks.
